quotes.topic_title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
quotes.text: Don't call it strategy, call it an action agenda.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Reframes strategy as a concrete set of actions rather than an abstract concept, pushing practitioners toward execution-focused thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
quotes.text: It's huge numbers of people out there willing to sell you advice on mission and your vision and your values, all these things that have to be in place before you can have strategy. That's not true.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional sequencing of strategy work by arguing you don’t need mission/vision/values exercises before making strategic choices.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
quotes.text: Begin to try to identify the one or two key challenges that can actually be addressed and what are we going to do about it?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Offers a practical starting point for strategy: narrow to 1–2 addressable challenges and immediately connect them to action.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
quotes.text: What are the coherent actions we're going to do to take these on?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Introduces the idea of “coherent actions” as a core strategy test—actions should reinforce each other toward the chosen challenge.

quotes.topic_title: Opening: Strategy as an action agenda
quotes.text: That's the essence of what you're doing when you're thinking strategically.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Defines strategic thinking as the discipline of choosing and coordinating actions to tackle key challenges, not producing lofty statements.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Richard shares the concrete elements that make a good strategy, why we'd be better off calling them action agendas rather than strategies, why every great strategy starts with a clear diagnosis of the biggest challenge that you face.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical strategy methodology: start with diagnosis, focus on concrete elements, and treat strategy as an action agenda.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, how to actually lay out a strategy, why organizational dynamics are often the biggest hindrance to winning strategies and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a counterintuitive blocker—internal dynamics—often outweighing external competition in strategy execution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Richard was a longtime professor at UCLA Anderson School of Management, was on the faculty of Harvard Business School, and he's consulted on strategy with companies like Microsoft, Apple and Intel, and also with government organizations like the US Army Special Ops Command, and folks like Donald Rumsfeld.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes breadth of real-world strategy application across top tech companies and high-stakes government contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And these pop-ups are becoming less and less effective since most users don't read what they say, they just want to close them as soon as possible.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive reality: common onboarding tactics can degrade in effectiveness as users learn to ignore them.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They use AI to get closer to user intent, so they have search and chat products that let users describe what they're trying to do in their own words and then see personalized results like customer walkthroughs or actions.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Offers an actionable methodology for product enablement: shift from feature-push to intent-driven assistance with personalized guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And they do pop-ups too, but their nudges are based on in-product behaviors like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a practical rule for interventions: trigger nudges from behavioral signals (confusion/intent) rather than generic prompts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 15 million end-users have interacted with CommandBar.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals scale and real-world usage.

quotes.topic_title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
quotes.text: Well, a strategy is a design for overcoming a high-stakes challenge.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A crisp definition that reframes strategy as challenge-centered design rather than vague goal-setting.

quotes.topic_title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
quotes.text: It's a mixture of policy and action designed to deal with a challenge.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: An actionable mental model: strategy must combine guiding policy with concrete actions aimed at a specific challenge.

quotes.topic_title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
quotes.text: So strategy is always about dealing with an issue, a challenge, a problem.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A counter to “strategy as vision”: it insists strategy starts with diagnosing and addressing a real problem.

quotes.topic_title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
quotes.text: The challenge could have an upside. It could be, "Oh geez, we were fooling around in the back 40 and we discovered oil, what we do?" Or it could be negative, could be that new innovation is driving us out of the market.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Concrete examples showing strategy applies to both opportunity capture and threat response, anchored in real situations.

quotes.topic_title: What strategy is: overcoming high-stakes challenges
quotes.text: The Greeks elected 10 Strategoi to serve as strategic leaders at Athens.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A memorable origin point that ties “strategy” to accountable leadership focused on urgent civic challenges.

quotes.topic_title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
quotes.text: And I gradually came to the realization all strategy is problem solving.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Reframes strategy away from buzzwords and planning artifacts toward a concrete discipline: solving a specific challenge.

quotes.topic_title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
quotes.text: So part of what a diagnosis is, is a decision about what you're going to pay attention to and the hypothesis for several hypotheses about what's going on, how do things connect together.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Gives a practical definition of “diagnosis” as focused attention plus testable causal hypotheses, not just analysis.

quotes.topic_title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
quotes.text: And yet, when I say that, it flies in the face of, as I was writing that, I had a client who had 17 priorities.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how “many priorities” is often the opposite of a real guiding policy.

quotes.topic_title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
quotes.text: Well, that's the word priority, it means the first.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A memorable linguistic reset that forces teams to choose what truly comes first rather than maintain a laundry list.

quotes.topic_title: The kernel: diagnosis, guiding policy, coherent action
quotes.text: You shouldn't do things that fight each other.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Captures the core test of coherent action: initiatives must reinforce rather than contradict one another.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
quotes.text: You have a diagnosis. Well, what's going on? You see the challenge of how do we adapt to it? You create a guiding policy that you're going to invest in one of the major leaders and that you're going to begin to incorporate that into your search engine. And then you have coherent actions. You actually do some of these things.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A concrete example that lays out Rumelt’s core strategy framework: diagnosis → guiding policy → coherent actions.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
quotes.text: It's not rocket science. The difficulty is that companies don't do that.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that strategy failure is usually execution and coherence failure, not lack of intelligence or complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
quotes.text: It's strategic assembly without any synthesis.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A memorable diagnosis of a common failure mode: collecting initiatives (e.g., acquisitions) without integrating them into a coherent strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
quotes.text: So strategy's not mysterious. What's mysterious to me, what was mysterious to me and what remains mysterious to me is how so many organizational leaders don't do it.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that strategy is inherently complex by pointing to leadership behavior as the real bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Concrete examples and why organizations fail
quotes.text: They create bad strategy. They do something that they say is strategy and then it's not.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A crisp warning that labeling a plan “strategy” doesn’t make it one—coherence and follow-through are the differentiators.

quotes.topic_title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
quotes.text: But abstract, high-level goals, they're not strategy, they're something else. They're ambitions. And ambitions are not a strategy. A list of all the different things you wish would happen is not strategy.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Clarifies a core bad-strategy pattern: confusing aspirational goals with an actual strategy practitioners can execute.

quotes.topic_title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
quotes.text: And the strategy basically that these people had written said the 17 agencies should work together more effectively.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how “strategy” often degenerates into a vague wish (better coordination) rather than a plan to solve a real constraint.

quotes.topic_title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
quotes.text: But there's no sensible... why is it hard to coordinate? What are the barriers to this? This has been going on for 34 years now. What's holding it back? What is a problem we have to solve? It's not there.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic checklist: name the barriers and the solvable problem, not just the desired outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
quotes.text: Bad strategy also is fluff. People will use fancy words to describe their situation. Since I wrote that, the term word salad has become common.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Memorable warning that abstraction and jargon often mask the absence of real strategic thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Bad strategy patterns: goals, fluff, missing diagnosis
quotes.text: So lacking diagnosis is one of the key reasons for bad strategy.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Distills the most important failure mode: without a clear diagnosis, coherent action can’t follow.

quotes.topic_title: Focus and the danger of too many priorities
quotes.text: We work best when we concentrate. We're more effective when we concentrate on a few things, a few people, a few... focus, it's the fundamental source of power and strategy. Trying to do too many different things is defocusing.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A direct, actionable principle: strategic effectiveness comes from concentrating effort on a small set of priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Focus and the danger of too many priorities
quotes.text: But to burn that black thread, there has to be a source of power, the sun. There has to be a focus, that's the magnifying that to the power. And it has to be a target that can be affected. It has to be a black thread, not white thread. And that sequence is part of strategic action.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A memorable framework (power + focus + affectable target) that practitioners can use to test whether a strategy can actually produce results.

quotes.topic_title: Focus and the danger of too many priorities
quotes.text: And it has to be a target that can be affected or achieved.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A practical filter for prioritization: choose objectives you can realistically influence rather than aspirational but uncontrollable goals.

quotes.topic_title: Focus and the danger of too many priorities
quotes.text: One of the big issues in strategy is simply the organization, complex organizations particularly. You have a hard time focusing energy because of all the different interests.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A contrarian organizational insight: strategy often fails not from lack of ideas, but from internal interest-driven diffusion of effort.

quotes.topic_title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
quotes.text: For a strategy you need to exploit in asymmetry of some kind.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Defines a core strategy test: if you can’t name an asymmetry you can exploit, you don’t yet have a strategy with power.

quotes.topic_title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
quotes.text: Being first to recognize something can be a source of power.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Highlights a practical advantage source practitioners can pursue: earlier insight/recognition rather than just better execution.

quotes.topic_title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
quotes.text: On the other hand, having a well-established reputation of a certain type can be the opposite of power because people don't expect you to be able to do something new.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that “strengths” like reputation can become constraints when you need to change what the market believes you can do.

quotes.topic_title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
quotes.text: When Gerstner took over IBM as it was failing in the face of the microprocessor revolution, he recognized that their primary asset, their source of power, was that they were respected and they had [inaudible 00:30:38] into every large corporation on the planet.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Concrete example of power as customer access/footprint—an exploitable asymmetry that can anchor a turnaround strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Power in strategy: asymmetry and advantage sources
quotes.text: So I start, as I said earlier, with the symmetries. In what way is my company different than other companies? In what way is my team different? What do we know that other people don't know? What do we possess that other people don't possess?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Gives a repeatable diagnostic method for finding power: enumerate differences in knowledge, assets, and capabilities versus competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
quotes.text: the power that new business models are exploiting is the power of the user base. What we called years ago, network effects, where the more users you have, the more useful a product is.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Defines a core modern source of competitive power as user-base-driven network effects.

quotes.topic_title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
quotes.text: Amazon. Get big fast because the economics are amazing.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Highlights speed-to-scale as a strategic imperative when network effects and scale economics dominate.

quotes.topic_title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
quotes.text: the suspicion is that size is what matters, that the size of the data that you could put into the learning algorithm is going to make your AI better.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Connects generative AI advantage to data scale, implying increasing returns for leaders with larger datasets.

quotes.topic_title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
quotes.text: It's very hard for Bing to catch up because Bing doesn't have as much data to train on.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Concrete example of how data/network scale can create persistent asymmetry against challengers.

quotes.topic_title: Modern power: network effects and scale dynamics
quotes.text: Now, the way you get around all that is by being specialized, by owning a particular approach that isn't the market leader's approach.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Actionable competitive guidance: specialize to avoid head-to-head scale battles with incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
quotes.text: To undertake a strategy that you think will work, you've got to have a reason that it makes sense and that reason is derived from some source of power, some source of advantage.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Defines “power” as the core justification that makes a strategy plausibly succeed rather than relying on hope.

quotes.topic_title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
quotes.text: All those things are sources of the power that you use to make it not an even bet.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A crisp mental model: good strategy identifies the asymmetry that changes the odds in your favor.

quotes.topic_title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
quotes.text: And in business, statistically, if you come to me and you say, I'm going to open a new restaurant. What should my strategy be? My answer would be don't open a restaurant. Invest in the S&P 500 because the statistics are that new restaurants fail.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Uses base rates to challenge naive entrepreneurship and forces the question: what advantage overcomes the default odds?

quotes.topic_title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
quotes.text: So there, where's the asymmetry here? Where's the source of power where you go from the odds... The standard odds in this game are against people where you think the odds are in your favor.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic prompt for strategy reviews: explicitly locate the asymmetry that flips the base-rate expectation.

quotes.topic_title: Where power fits in the kernel and execution
quotes.text: So we had all these different objectives. It doesn't work. You need to have a focus on something achievable.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Highlights execution failure from incoherent, conflicting goals and argues for narrowing to achievable objectives.

quotes.topic_title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
quotes.text: If you don't have access to other times and other places and other things that have happened, it's very hard to think strategically about the situation you're in because there isn't a science of strategy.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Strategy is framed as fundamentally non-scientific, so practitioners must build judgment by drawing on historical analogies.

quotes.topic_title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
quotes.text: Go back and you can go online and look at the Wall Street Journal of the New York Times from that era and start in September of 1928 and just look at the front page every day, which I've done, and you can see it unfold and it's a surprise to everyone.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A concrete method for practicing diagnosis: read contemporaneous sources day-by-day to see how uncertainty and misinterpretation unfold in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
quotes.text: The most important intellectual tool we have is to think again, to say, okay, I came up with this diagnosis because I thought this and I thought this. Is there another way to look at this situation? Is there a bigger piece of wood over there than I can grab onto?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A repeatable mental model for improving strategic judgment: treat first explanations as provisional and actively search for better diagnoses.

quotes.topic_title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
quotes.text: So if you look at capital goods, most capital goods that the public buys, the adoption curve goes up like this, it peaks, and it declines and then it comes back up again. Because there comes a point where everybody who can afford one has got one, and then the new sales drop off.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A diagnostic pattern (adoption/saturation cycle) that can be applied to markets to anticipate demand cliffs and second-wave replacement cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Using history to build diagnosis and judgment
quotes.text: 1929, everybody could afford a car, had a car, and the auto industry began... First signs of the Great Depression were in the auto industry.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: A specific, testable hypothesis linking macro downturns to saturation in a major capital-good category—useful as an example of forming your own diagnosis from patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of fast-growing companies like Gusto, Com, Quora and Modern Treasury, trust Vanta to help build, scale, manage, and demonstrate their security and compliance programs and get ready for audits in weeks, not months.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Vanta)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark (“weeks, not months”) and social proof examples for accelerating compliance and audit readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor message (Vanta)
quotes.context: Quantifies adoption and the potential automation impact (“up to 90%”) for teams evaluating compliance tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Do you have any advice for just how to lay out a strategy? As you talk I think of there's a section. Diagnosis, a section. Guiding principles, a section. Actions, and then there's power in there and the guiding policy.
quotes.speaker: Host (Lenny)
quotes.context: Outlines a practical strategy-writing structure (Diagnosis → Guiding principles/policy → Actions) that a PM could directly apply.

quotes.topic_title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
quotes.text: First, it's really important to understand the challenge, the problem. Diagnosis is not merely understanding the world, it's understanding the challenge you face. What makes it hard?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Reframes “diagnosis” as explicitly naming the hard part of the problem, a practical starting point for writing strategy.

quotes.topic_title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
quotes.text: So my two pieces of advice, anybody that's actually trying to do this is, A, state the problem, and, B, don't call it a strategy, call it an action agenda, that you're not creating a strategy, you're creating an action agenda. What are we going to do about this problem?
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Gives a simple, practitioner-friendly template: name the problem and turn it into a concrete action agenda.

quotes.topic_title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
quotes.text: It's not five years out and 10 years out. It's not your general mission to build a better world, it's none of that.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Pushes back on common “strategy” tropes, emphasizing near-term problem-solving over vague long-range statements.

quotes.topic_title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
quotes.text: So you're choosing a challenge. You're choosing, of the possible challenges you could face up to, you can't do them all. So there's a focus thing. You're choosing which challenge to focus on, and that challenge has to be, A, important, and, B, it has to be achievable.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Defines a selection criterion for strategic focus: pick an important, achievable (addressable) challenge rather than trying to tackle everything.

quotes.topic_title: How to write strategy: start with the challenge
quotes.text: These are things we're going to do, not goals we're going to achieve. These are things we're going to do, action steps.
quotes.speaker: Richard Rumelt
quotes.context: Clarifies that a usable strategy document should specify actions (doings) rather than aspirational outcomes (goals).
